A stroke occurs when blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin dying within minutes. It is a medical emergency. The two main types are ischemic (blocked artery) and hemorrhagic (bleeding).

questions.q: What are the warning signs of stroke?
questions.a: Remember FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency. Other signs include sudden numbness, confusion, trouble seeing, difficulty walking, dizziness, severe headache. Every minute counts - call ambulance immediately.

Ischemic strokes (87%) are caused by blood clots blocking arteries. Hemorrhagic strokes are caused by bleeding from ruptured blood vessel. Risk factors include high blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, high cholesterol, obesity, atrial fibrillation, and family history.

Diagnosis includes physical and neurological examination, CT or MRI scan to determine stroke type and location, blood tests, carotid ultrasound, echocardiogram, and angiography. Quick diagnosis is crucial for appropriate treatment.

questions.q: What is the treatment for stroke?
questions.a: For ischemic stroke, clot-busting drugs (tPA) must be given within 4.5 hours. Mechanical thrombectomy can remove clots. Hemorrhagic stroke may require surgery. All patients need rehabilitation (physical, speech, occupational therapy) and medication to prevent recurrence.

Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) or mini-stroke causes temporary stroke-like symptoms lasting minutes to hours but no permanent damage. It is a serious warning sign - 1 in 3 people who have TIA will have major stroke. Seek immediate medical attention.

Many strokes are preventable through controlling blood pressure, managing diabetes, lowering cholesterol, not smoking, maintaining healthy weight, regular exercise, limiting alcohol, eating healthy diet, and treating atrial fibrillation.

Complications include paralysis, difficulty speaking or swallowing, memory loss, emotional problems (depression), pain, behavioral changes, reduced ability to care for oneself, and increased risk of recurrent stroke. Early rehabilitation improves recovery.

Rehabilitation helps recover lost abilities and learn compensatory strategies. It includes physical therapy (movement, balance), occupational therapy (daily activities), speech therapy (communication, swallowing), and psychological support. Recovery varies by individual.

questions.q: How common are strokes in India?
questions.a: Approximately 1.6 million people suffer from stroke in India annually. It is a leading cause of death and disability. Stroke incidence is increasing, affecting younger age groups. About 16 lakh Indians suffer strokes each year.

questions.q: What is the golden hour for stroke?
questions.a: The first 4.5 hours after stroke onset is critical for treatment with clot-busting drugs. Earlier treatment leads to better outcomes. Time lost is brain lost - immediate emergency medical care can save lives and reduce disability.

Yes, though less common. Risk factors in young adults include high blood pressure, smoking, drug abuse, blood disorders, heart conditions, pregnancy/postpartum, and contraceptive use. Lifestyle modifications and managing risk factors are important.

questions.q: What is the difference between stroke and heart attack?
questions.a: Stroke affects the brain when blood supply is interrupted. Heart attack affects the heart when coronary arteries are blocked. Both are vascular emergencies requiring immediate treatment. They share common risk factors like high blood pressure and smoking.

Recovery varies widely. Some recover completely, others have permanent disabilities. Factors affecting recovery include stroke severity, location, age, overall health, and timing/intensity of rehabilitation. Most recovery occurs in first 3-6 months, but improvement can continue for years.

Medications include antiplatelet drugs (aspirin, clopidogrel), anticoagulants (warfarin, newer agents for atrial fibrillation), blood pressure medications, statins for cholesterol, and diabetes medications. Medication choice depends on stroke cause and risk factors.

Cancer is a disease where abnormal cells grow uncontrollably and can invade other tissues. There are over 100 types of cancer. It can start anywhere in the body. Cancer cells can spread through blood and lymph systems (metastasis). Early detection improves treatment outcomes.

questions.q: How common is cancer in India?
questions.a: Cancer incidence in India was 70-90 per 100,000 population in 2014. About 2.5 million people live with cancer, with over 800,000 new cases and 550,000 deaths each year. Common cancers include breast, cervical, oral, lung, and colorectal.

Causes include genetic mutations, tobacco use, infections (HPV, Hepatitis), radiation exposure, carcinogenic chemicals, obesity, lack of physical activity, unhealthy diet, alcohol, and aging. Many cancers result from combination of genetic and environmental factors.

Warning signs include unexplained weight loss, persistent fatigue, fever, pain, skin changes, unusual bleeding or discharge, persistent cough, difficulty swallowing, changes in bowel/bladder habits, and lumps. However, many early cancers have no symptoms.

Diagnosis involves medical history, physical examination, blood tests (tumor markers), imaging (X-ray, CT, MRI, PET scan), biopsy (tissue sample examination), and genetic testing. Accurate diagnosis determines cancer type, stage, and best treatment approach.

Main treatments include surgery (remove tumor), chemotherapy (drugs to kill cancer cells), radiation therapy (high-energy beams), immunotherapy (boost immune system), targeted therapy (attack specific cancer cell features), and hormone therapy. Treatment depends on cancer type and stage.

Staging describes cancer size and spread. Stage 0 is in situ (localized), Stage I-III indicate increasing size/spread to nearby tissues, Stage IV means metastatic (spread to distant organs). Staging guides treatment decisions and prognosis.

Prevention includes not using tobacco, maintaining healthy weight, being physically active, eating healthy diet rich in fruits/vegetables, limiting alcohol, protecting from sun, getting vaccinated (HPV, Hepatitis B), and regular screening for early detection.

Chemotherapy uses drugs to kill rapidly dividing cancer cells. It can cure cancer, control growth, or relieve symptoms. Side effects include nausea, hair loss, fatigue, increased infection risk, and mouth sores. Different drugs work in different ways.

Radiation therapy uses high-energy rays to kill cancer cells or slow growth. It can be external (machine outside body) or internal (radioactive material placed inside body). Side effects depend on treatment area and dose.

Immunotherapy helps the immune system fight cancer. Types include checkpoint inhibitors, CAR T-cell therapy, cancer vaccines, and monoclonal antibodies. It has revolutionized treatment for some cancers with fewer side effects than chemotherapy.

About 5-10% of cancers are hereditary due to inherited gene mutations (BRCA1/2 for breast/ovarian, Lynch syndrome for colon). Family history increases risk. Genetic counseling and testing help assess risk and guide screening/prevention strategies.

Screening tests detect cancer before symptoms appear when treatment is most effective. Common screenings include mammography (breast), Pap smear (cervical), colonoscopy (colon), PSA (prostate), and low-dose CT (lung for high-risk). Follow recommended guidelines.

Palliative care focuses on relieving symptoms and improving quality of life for people with serious illnesses like cancer. It addresses physical, emotional, and spiritual needs. It can be provided alongside curative treatment and is not just end-of-life care.

Many cancers can be cured if detected early and treated appropriately. Cure rates vary by cancer type and stage. Some cancers can be controlled as chronic disease. Survival rates have improved significantly with advances in treatment and early detection.

Remission means signs and symptoms of cancer reduce or disappear. Complete remission means all signs are gone; partial remission means some remain. Remission doesn't necessarily mean cure. Regular follow-up is needed to monitor for recurrence.

Metastatic or Stage IV cancer has spread from original site to distant organs through bloodstream or lymph system. Common sites include lungs, liver, bones, and brain. It is more difficult to treat but advances in therapy are improving outcomes.

Tobacco contains over 70 cancer-causing chemicals. It damages DNA and impairs body's ability to repair damage. Smoking causes lung, mouth, throat, esophagus, bladder, kidney, pancreas, and other cancers. Quitting at any age reduces risk.

Pap smear detects precancerous changes in cervix. HPV testing detects virus causing cervical cancer. Women should start screening at age 21 and continue as recommended. HPV vaccination prevents most cervical cancers. India has high cervical cancer burden.

questions.q: What support is available for cancer patients?
questions.a: Support includes medical team, counselors, support groups, nutritionists, social workers, pain management specialists, and financial assistance programs. Organizations provide education, resources, and emotional support for patients and families throughout cancer journey.

Diarrheal diseases are characterized by loose, watery stools occurring three or more times in a day. They are caused by infections (viral, bacterial, parasitic), food intolerance, or medications. Diarrhea leads to dehydration, especially dangerous in children and elderly.

Common causes include viral infections (rotavirus, norovirus), bacterial infections (E. coli, Salmonella, Shigella), parasites (Giardia, amoeba), contaminated food/water, food allergies, medications, inflammatory bowel disease, and lactose intolerance.

Treatment includes oral rehydration solution (ORS) to replace fluids and electrolytes, zinc supplementation for children, continued feeding, and antibiotics only for bacterial causes. Most cases resolve in 2-3 days. Seek medical help if severe or prolonged.

Oral Rehydration Solution is a specific mixture of water, salt, and sugar that effectively treats dehydration from diarrhea. WHO recommends low-osmolarity ORS. It has saved millions of lives, especially children under 5.

questions.q: How can diarrheal diseases be prevented?
questions.a: Prevention includes safe drinking water, proper sanitation, handwashing with soap, safe food handling, exclusive breastfeeding for infants, rotavirus vaccination, and improved hygiene practices.

Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children worldwide. It spreads through fecal-oral route. Symptoms include severe watery diarrhea, vomiting, and fever. Rotavirus vaccine has significantly reduced incidence and deaths.

questions.q: When should I seek medical help for diarrhea?
questions.a: Seek help if: signs of dehydration (no urination for 8 hours, sunken eyes, dry mouth, lethargy), blood in stool, high fever, severe abdominal pain, diarrhea lasting more than 2 days in children or 5 days in adults, or elderly/immunocompromised patients.

Signs include decreased urination, dry mouth and tongue, no tears when crying, sunken eyes and cheeks, sunken soft spot in infants, unusual sleepiness or irritability, and rapid heartbeat. Severe dehydration is life-threatening and requires immediate medical attention.

Cholera is a severe bacterial diarrheal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae, transmitted through contaminated water. It causes profuse watery diarrhea (rice-water stools) leading to severe dehydration and death within hours if untreated. Treatment is with ORS and antibiotics.

Dysentery is diarrhea with blood and mucus, often accompanied by abdominal cramps. It is caused by bacteria (Shigella, E. coli) or parasites (Entamoeba). Treatment requires antibiotics or antiparasitic drugs based on the causative organism.

Jaundice is yellowing of skin and eyes due to excess bilirubin in blood. It indicates liver disease, bile duct obstruction, or excessive red blood cell breakdown. It is a symptom, not a disease itself. Newborn jaundice is common and usually harmless.

Causes include hepatitis (viral, alcoholic, autoimmune), liver cirrhosis, bile duct obstruction (gallstones, tumors), hemolytic anemia, inherited conditions (Gilbert's syndrome), and certain medications. In newborns, immature liver function causes physiological jaundice.
Symptoms include yellow skin and eyes, dark urine, pale stools, itching, fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever. Severity depends on underlying cause and bilirubin levels.

Diagnosis includes physical examination, blood tests (bilirubin levels, liver function tests, complete blood count), urine tests, imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI), and sometimes liver biopsy to identify underlying cause.

questions.q: What is the treatment for jaundice?
questions.a: Treatment depends on cause: treating underlying liver disease, removing bile duct obstruction, stopping offending medications, phototherapy for newborns, or managing hemolytic conditions. Maintaining hydration and nutrition is important.

Jaundice itself is not contagious, but if caused by infectious hepatitis (Hepatitis A, B, C, E), the infection can spread to others. Proper hygiene, vaccination, and avoiding sharing personal items prevent transmission.

Neonatal jaundice affects 60% of full-term and 80% of premature newborns in first week of life. It is usually physiological (harmless) due to immature liver. Treatment is phototherapy if bilirubin is very high. Breastfeeding jaundice resolves without intervention.

Gilbert's syndrome is a common inherited condition causing mild intermittent jaundice. It results from reduced enzyme activity for bilirubin processing. It is harmless, requires no treatment, and doesn't affect life expectancy. Jaundice may worsen with illness or stress.

Prevention depends on cause: vaccination against hepatitis, avoiding excessive alcohol, maintaining healthy weight, safe blood transfusions, practicing safe sex, avoiding sharing needles, and treating underlying liver conditions promptly.

Kernicterus is rare but serious brain damage from very high bilirubin levels in newborns. It causes permanent neurological problems including cerebral palsy, hearing loss, and developmental delays. Prevention through early detection and treatment of severe neonatal jaundice is crucial.

Gastroenteritis is inflammation of stomach and intestines, commonly called stomach flu. It causes diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and sometimes fever. It is usually caused by viral or bacterial infections and spreads through contaminated food, water, or person-to-person contact.

Causes include viruses (norovirus, rotavirus, adenovirus), bacteria (E. coli, Salmonella, Campylobacter, Shigella), parasites (Giardia), and occasionally toxins in food. Poor hygiene and contaminated food/water are main transmission routes.

Symptoms include watery diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, low-grade fever, headache, muscle aches, and fatigue. Symptoms usually appear 1-3 days after infection and last 1-10 days depending on cause.

Treatment focuses on preventing dehydration with oral rehydration solutions, clear fluids, and rest. Eat bland foods when able. Antibiotics are used only for bacterial causes. Most cases resolve without specific treatment in a few days.

questions.q: When should I see a doctor for gastroenteritis?
questions.a: Seek medical attention if: unable to keep liquids down for 24 hours, vomiting blood, severe dehydration signs, bloody or black stools, fever above 104°F, severe abdominal pain, symptoms lasting more than several days, or in infants/elderly/immunocompromised.

Prevention includes frequent handwashing with soap, especially before eating and after bathroom use, safe food handling and cooking, drinking clean water, avoiding sharing utensils, staying home when sick, and rotavirus vaccination for infants.

Yes, gastroenteritis is highly contagious, especially viral gastroenteritis. It spreads through fecal-oral route, contaminated food/water, or touching contaminated surfaces. Infected people can spread virus before symptoms appear and for days after recovery.

Food poisoning is gastroenteritis caused by eating contaminated food containing bacteria, viruses, parasites, or toxins. Common causes include Salmonella, E. coli, Staphylococcus, and Clostridium. Symptoms appear hours to days after eating contaminated food.

Norovirus is the most common cause of viral gastroenteritis in adults. It causes sudden onset of vomiting and diarrhea. It is highly contagious, spreads rapidly in closed settings, and there is no vaccine. Good hygiene prevents spread.

Some studies suggest certain probiotics may reduce duration and severity of diarrhea, especially in children with viral gastroenteritis. However, evidence is mixed. Consult healthcare provider before use, especially in immunocompromised individuals.

Leprosy (Hansen's disease) is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae bacteria affecting skin, peripheral nerves, and eyes. It is curable with multidrug therapy. India has the highest number of leprosy cases globally but has made significant progress in control.

Leprosy spreads through prolonged close contact with untreated infected person via respiratory droplets. It is not highly contagious. Most people have natural immunity. Early treatment prevents transmission and complications.

Symptoms include skin patches (lighter or darker than normal skin) with loss of sensation, numbness in hands/feet, muscle weakness, eye problems, and nasal stuffiness. Symptoms appear years after infection due to long incubation period.

Leprosy is treated with multidrug therapy (MDT) combining rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine for 6-12 months depending on type. Treatment is free under National Leprosy Eradication Programme. Early treatment prevents disabilities.

Yes, untreated leprosy can cause permanent nerve damage leading to muscle paralysis, loss of sensation, deformities of hands and feet, blindness, and facial disfigurement. Early diagnosis and treatment prevent these complications.

Yes, leprosy is completely curable with multidrug therapy. Once treatment starts, person is no longer infectious. India provides free diagnosis and treatment through government health centers under elimination program.

Leprosy elimination is defined as reducing prevalence to less than 1 case per 10,000 population. India achieved this goal in 2005 at national level. However, some districts still have higher rates requiring continued efforts for complete elimination.

Despite being curable, leprosy patients face stigma and discrimination due to historical misconceptions. Education, awareness, and social support help reduce stigma. Early diagnosis, complete treatment, and rehabilitation enable patients to lead normal lives.

Rabies is a fatal viral disease affecting the central nervous system, transmitted through bites or scratches from infected animals, primarily dogs. Once symptoms appear, it is almost always fatal. However, it is preventable through post-exposure prophylaxis and vaccination.

Rabies virus is transmitted through saliva of infected animals entering body through bites, scratches, or contact with broken skin/mucous membranes. Dogs are responsible for 99% of human rabies cases in India. Other animals include cats, monkeys, bats.

Early symptoms include fever, headache, tingling at bite site. Progresses to agitation, confusion, hyperactivity, hallucinations, hydrophobia (fear of water), difficulty swallowing, paralysis, coma, and death. Symptoms appear 1-3 months after exposure.

questions.q: What should I do if bitten by an animal?
questions.a: Immediately wash wound thoroughly with soap and water for 15 minutes, apply antiseptic, and seek medical attention immediately for post-exposure prophylaxis (rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin). Do not wait for symptoms. Early treatment saves lives.

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) prevents rabies after exposure. It includes wound cleaning, rabies immunoglobulin (for severe exposures), and series of rabies vaccine doses (on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and sometimes 28). It is effective if given before symptoms appear.

Once symptoms appear, rabies is almost always fatal with no cure. However, it is preventable through immediate post-exposure prophylaxis after animal bite and pre-exposure vaccination for high-risk individuals (veterinarians, animal handlers).

Prevention includes mass dog vaccination, avoiding contact with stray animals, vaccinating pets, avoiding wildlife, pre-exposure vaccination for high-risk people, and immediate post-exposure treatment after any animal bite.

questions.q: What is the prevalence of rabies in India?
questions.a: India accounts for about 36% of global rabies deaths, with approximately 20,000 deaths annually. Most cases are from dog bites. National Rabies Control Programme focuses on dog vaccination, awareness, and ensuring availability of vaccines and immunoglobulin.

Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is a viral infection transmitted by Culex mosquitoes causing brain inflammation. It primarily affects children in rural areas. While most infections are mild, severe cases can cause permanent neurological damage or death. Vaccination prevents JE.

JE virus is transmitted through bites of infected Culex mosquitoes, which breed in rice paddies and flooded fields. The virus cycles between mosquitoes, pigs, and water birds. Humans are dead-end hosts. Peak transmission occurs during monsoon and post-monsoon seasons.

Most infections are asymptomatic or cause mild fever. Severe cases develop sudden fever, headache, vomiting, confusion, seizures, paralysis, and coma. Symptoms appear 5-15 days after infection. Case fatality rate is 20-30%. Survivors may have permanent neurological deficits.

questions.q: How is JE diagnosed and treated?
questions.a: Diagnosis is through blood and CSF tests detecting JE antibodies or viral RNA. There is no specific antiviral treatment. Management is supportive with care for seizures, respiratory support, and complications. Prevention through vaccination is crucial.

questions.q: Is there a vaccine for JE?
questions.a: Yes, safe and effective JE vaccines are available. In India, JE vaccine is included in Universal Immunization Programme in endemic states. Children receive two doses. Vaccination is recommended for people living in or traveling to endemic areas.

Prevention includes JE vaccination, mosquito control measures, using insecticide-treated nets, wearing protective clothing, using mosquito repellents, and avoiding outdoor activities during peak mosquito biting times (dusk and dawn) in endemic areas.
Thyroid Disorders is a health condition that affects many people in India. It requires proper diagnosis and treatment.
Thyroid Disorders has various causes including genetic factors, lifestyle, environmental factors, and sometimes infections.

questions.q: What are the symptoms of thyroid disorders?
questions.a: Common symptoms of Thyroid Disorders vary by individual but typically include specific manifestations requiring medical attention.
Diagnosis of Thyroid Disorders involves medical history, physical examination, laboratory tests, and sometimes imaging studies.

questions.q: What is the treatment for thyroid disorders?
questions.a: Treatment for Thyroid Disorders depends on severity and may include medications, lifestyle changes, and in some cases, surgical intervention.
Many cases of Thyroid Disorders can be prevented through healthy lifestyle, regular checkups, and managing risk factors.

questions.q: What are risk factors for thyroid disorders?
questions.a: Risk factors for Thyroid Disorders include age, family history, lifestyle factors, and certain medical conditions.
Some forms of Thyroid Disorders have genetic components, though environmental and lifestyle factors also play important roles.

questions.q: What complications can thyroid disorders cause?
questions.a: If left untreated, Thyroid Disorders can lead to various complications affecting quality of life and overall health.

questions.q: How common is thyroid disorders in India?
questions.a: Thyroid Disorders affects a significant portion of the Indian population, with prevalence varying by region and demographic factors.

questions.q: What lifestyle changes help with thyroid disorders?
questions.a: Managing Thyroid Disorders often requires lifestyle modifications including diet, exercise, stress management, and avoiding triggers.

questions.q: What medications are used for thyroid disorders?
questions.a: Various medications are available to treat Thyroid Disorders, chosen based on individual patient needs and disease severity.
Prognosis for Thyroid Disorders varies - some cases can be cured completely, while others require long-term management.

questions.q: When should I see a doctor for thyroid disorders?
questions.a: Seek medical attention if you experience symptoms of Thyroid Disorders or have risk factors. Early diagnosis improves outcomes.

questions.q: What tests are needed for thyroid disorders?
questions.a: Diagnostic tests for Thyroid Disorders may include blood work, imaging studies, biopsies, or specialized examinations depending on the condition.
